summary: This document is a chain of emails from December 2019 discussing logistical arrangements for a victim's therapy, including payment through the Epstein Victim Assistance Fund (EVAF) and confusion over the submission of a Crime Victims Compensation (CVC) application. It involves coordination between FBI agents and victim advocates.

persons.name: Bellin
persons.context: FBI agent from the Seattle Division, Bellinham Resident Agency, involved in coordinating victim assistance and communication with OVS.

persons.name: Jen
persons.context: Referred to in the context of seeking therapy and submitting a CVC application; an FBI agent spoke with her.

connections.description: Bellin, an FBI agent, is involved in assisting Jen with victim services, including therapy funding and CVC application issues.

events.title: Therapy Arrangement Discussion
events.description: Email chain begins discussing Jen's need for therapy, identification of a therapist, and funding through EVAF.

events.title: Therapist Appointment Scheduled
events.description: Jen independently made an appointment with a therapist for 7pm, with rates provided; FBI asked to explain payment.

events.title: Email Forward Regarding Therapy
events.description: Email forwarded noting Jen had been seeing a therapist since meeting the correspondent and received an offer for 'free therapy for life'.

locations: FBI Seattle Division Bellinham Resident Agency
NY CVC (New York Crime Victims Compensation)
keyFacts: A victim, Jen, is seeking therapy and has identified a therapist, with discussions about payment through the Epstein Victim Assistance Fund (EVAF).
There is confusion over whether Jen submitted a Crime Victims Compensation (CVC) application, with NY CVC reporting no record of it.
An email mentions Jen received an offer for 'free therapy for life', but the form is not the CVC form, raising questions about the therapist's identity.
FBI agents and victim advocates are coordinating to assist Jen, emphasizing the importance of streamlined communication with a single victim services (VS) contact.
